data.message: Hello TSP members! Many thanks to those of you who have done our first follow-up survey sent out two weeks ago. For those of you who haven't, don't forget to check your email and complete it for a $20 gift card! You’ll earn an additional $20 at the end if you fill out all surveys!

Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out last week. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!
When do we get our $ for commenting on the posts/discussions?
Same here 10283

Hello TSP members! Today's post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email today for our first follow-up survey. You will receive a $20 gift card upon completion.We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participationAlthough we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.
Yay! Thanks. I don't know what I would have done without y'all
#88: How else will your life be different when you're living smoke free? Tell us some of the things you're most excited for in the future! #knowyourself
Larger chunks of time to do things, no nagging urge to smoke in the morning, etc!
More money. Lol
Better breath!
Money, health, and freedom
#89: After your quit date, go to the dentist and have your teeth cleaned! Is there anyone you wouldn’t mind kissing with a fresh mouth? ;) #reinforcement
I already had mine
I have an appointment in a few weeks actually haha.
Making one soon
#90: Pass the torch! What advice would you give to other smokers who are trying to quit? #support
Find what works best for you. No matter what others opinions are.
Try different things and don't give up on quitting.
Constantly think of the benefits
Stay strong. It's worth it
#87: What are you gaining by quitting? Anyone got a savings jar? #reinforcement
I buy myself something every time I go a couple weeks without smoking.
I remind myself every day. I don't save I just buy myself wine
Health and finance benefits!

#86: The night before your Quit Date, make sure you've gotten rid of all your cigarettes, lighters, matches and ashtrays from your car and home. Would/did you do this? If you can, take a picture of your night-before purge and post it here. #control
I didn't take any pictures
I'm working on my quit list now
I didn't take any pictures either but my car smells ten times better!
No pictures because all of my junk is already gone!
With the 90 days being almost over I am curious to hear about your experience: What is the most important thing you have learned from TSP? #TDII
Stay strong! And coping.
Hi 10261 - thanks for sharing and good to hear from you! How are you holding up? Still smoke free?
Absolutely. Still vaping. 1.5mg and going strong.
That's great - cool, so you're already down from last time we talked :) Do you feel a difference when you switch to a lower nicotine concentration?
The first few days is rough but I deal. Then it meets what I need it to. I'm anxious to go down to no nicotine but I know I'm not ready.

Very interesting - thanks for sharing your experience 10261! Have you also tried to mix up the situations in which you are vaping? This may be important for your body to unlearn some of the craving and the connection between a certain setting and nicotine.
I'm very random with it. I already broke the rituals. It's mostly when I can't handle the withdrawal anymore. Because I'm one of those.

Good job 10261! Unfortunately, we can't choose how strong of a withdrawal reaction our body gives us... I think you are on the right track though with slowly decreasing the nicotine content and I understand that you are afraid of reducing to 0 nicotine. Have you also been practicing other strategies to cope with cravings and withdrawal? What has been most helpful?
This is literally the only thing that has had me smoke free for over a day. I've tried everything else.

I'm glad to hear that you have found something that works for you 10261! One thing you could do to work your way towards 0mg nicotine is to gradually decrease your concentration even further but still not go down to 0. Or you could try to keep track of your puffs and reduce the number of puffs you take each day or increase the time interval between puffs. Any of these sound like they may help?
Having cigarettes on my mind constantly but in a way that makes me not want them everyday helped
Hi 10215 - glad to hear it! How much do you smoke right now if at all?
1.5mg is the lowest you can find. And that's hard. It's barely any

Ok I see 10261! I was wondering if one could custom-mix different concentrations to go even lower, but maybe that's not possible? So another way may be to slowly vape less. Have you thought about giving it a try?
A few a week at the most when I am out with friends
It's logistically possible but not real world feasible. I'll make it there. I'm sure I'm not wanting to push myself too fast.
10215 - it's great that you have been able to reduce your smoking! Are you still committed to getting rid of these last few cigarettes? How could you do it? What has been working best for you?
I think the tips for replacing smoking with other activities have been the most helpful.
10261 - sounds like you are still very committed and motivated, that's very cool to hear! And not pushing too fast is a really good strategy!
Great to hear 10283 - we are all very proud of your success!
Thanks, Johannes! TSP has been great.
Thank you 10283 - it's been our pleasure!
Very committed. Keeping busy and going to the gym help the most for sure
Great 10215! And what can you do when you go out with friends and have an urge to smoke? What are your options?
I've got to run. Great talking to you guys! Take care and keep up the good work!

#85: If you're having trouble shaking those smoky-thoughts, play the Milk-Off game and reset your mind to overcome cravings. After five minutes of playing, did you feel a difference? #reinforcement http://buff.ly/1HH0GfO
Absolutely
I normally just play a puzzle game. Lol
Tetris is a helpful game!
Tetris is great

#84: Your smoking-substitutions can give you time to do things you haven't gotten around to. Choose one of the following that you'd like to do instead of smoke, or tell us your own: • Do puzzles or crafts if you’re used to smoking while watching TV• Eat raw vegetables, like carrot sticks• Read a book or magazine#feelinghealthy
I love puzzle books and even coloring books
I knit and crochet.
Eat raw vegetables. I live on a farm
Read a book!
#83: Planning ahead can make all the difference for quitting. Tell us your plan for resisting nicotine cravings during nighttime after your quit date. #control
I normally don't have cravings in between bedtime and waking up
Go to sleep earlier
I just read or clean now
Read and watching tv or shower

data.message: #78: Try going about your day without carrying around your matches or lighter. Tell us what it was like being without your trusty flame and how it prepared you for your quit day. #feelinghealthy
That was one of the first things I did. It sucked
I felt naked
Made me give up on my idea of a cigarette every time it came up
I destroyed all smoking related items. It was liberating! It was odd the first few days though.
Thanks for doing this! :)

#82: Do you think Obama is lifting his mood with a quick 5-minute call to a friend? Studies say calling someone to offer support can motivate you as well. So who will you call during your next 5 spare minutes? #reinforcement
My best friend
My wife
My husband
My best friend, my mom, and my fiancé

#81: When you're stressed out at work or in class, how will you get through cigarette cravings? Countdown relaxation techniques can be helpful, but what are YOU planning on doing when things get crazy? #control
Just deal with it instead of finding something to immediately calm me down.
Text my husband let him know I'm stressed and miss smoking. He will remind me how bad smoking is
I just deal
Gum

#80: Before your Quit Date arrives, take some time to think about your afternoon routine and how you will change it to keep you from giving in to cravings. Post your strategy here and maybe inspire someone else in the group! #control
My afternoon coffee makes me want to but I've been staying strong.
Cleaning but now I listen to music
My situation was somewhat unique because I got a new job which drastically changed my routine. When I get home, I immediately shower instead of having a cigarette.
Cleaning

#79: A common trigger for ex-smokers: driving or getting stuck in traffic. You could chew sugarless gum or listen to the radio to combat your craving. What else could you do instead of smoking when you're behind the wheel? #control
Take the ashtray out.
I take back roads during busy times of the day to avoid this
Eat a healthy snack
I have gum and I sing with my fiancé on long rides
How do you feel about your quitting now? Still feeling committed to becoming smoke free? #TDII
Being smoke free has been great so far!
Very cool 10283 - what do you do to keep up your motivation and to reward yourself?
I just think if my daughter coming soon and how I don't wanna be a smoker dad. I reward myself by taking my wife out to eat and things like that.
Great! Have you experienced any risky situations? Any lapses or slips at all?
Not many risky situations. No slip ups!

Sounds like you are well on track - good job! Should you ever get into a risky situation and encounter a slip up (not that I think it will happen to you, but I believe it's better to be prepared in any case) - check out this quick guide and remember: A lapse is not a relapse, it's always up to you how to continue. http://smokefree.gov/slips
The urge to quit gets stronger everyday
#77: A common trigger for many smokers is waking up in the morning. Showering right away when you wake up is one way to interrupt this common smoking trigger. How would you do it? #control
I just make myself not.
I have an excersise routine I do in place of smoking each morning!
Eat a snack or drink a shake
I have cinnamon sugar free candy and gum beside the bed

#75: Try this! Make one 24-hr quit attempt. #feelinghealthy
Done!
Did it
Did it
Tried it

Take a pic of yours and show it off here, or tell us what you’re putting in it! #control
With me vaping I'm weaning myself off nicotine. I'm doing great. Down to 1.5mg =)
Good job 10261! I just keep food on hand.
Healthy snacks gum drinks
I have fat free gum

#73: What could a friend or family member do to help you stay on the Quit Wagon? Choose your favorite option below (or come up with your own), then ask for it from a supporter! What kind of response did you get? #support• Be available to call or hang out when you feel the urge to smoke• Help you clean your home or car so they no longer smell like smoke• Send you weekly emails asking how you’re doing and reminding you of your reasons to quit
All I need is someone to talk to. Its cool.
Keep me distracted and talk to me
A mix of both of 10261 and 10285's answers!
Help me keep my car clean
#72: Let all your FB friends know about your mission to be smoke-free. Share with us what kinds of reactions your friends had. #support
Last time I did it I got a mix of yeah right and horrau
Same as 10261
I would do this but I'm friends with a lot of co-workers who never knew I smoked. I'd like to keep it that way haha.
Ditto what 10283 said lol
Have you ever noticed a connection between smoking and your mood? Is there an emotional state that gets you to light up more frequently? #TDII
I always pick up smoking again when it's an extremely emotional time.
Hi 10261 - yes, that's definitely very common problem. What is your plan to deal with these emotions next time?
I would only smoke a lot in stressful situations. But smoking would make me jittery!
Thanks for sharing 10283. Sounds like smoking did not help all that much. How do you deal with stressful situations now? What has changed?
I usually just walk away for a few minutes and relax. If I can't leave the situation, I just suffer through it!
The important part is that you make it through and it sounds like it's working for you! Great job! :) How does it feel to be smokefree?
Thanks! Still getting used to it, but it definitely feels better than smoking!
Keep reminding yourself of your most important reasons, practice your strategies, and don't forget to reward yourself!
I smoke when I'm angry and talkative
I smoke when I'm upset and it calms me down

#71: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I gave myself one treat for each week that I didn’t smoke. One week I bought myself flowers, the next I took a friend out to the movies, and the next I bought myself a sweater. Next week, I’m going to a concert." Share how will you reward yourself when you quit! #reinforcement
That's amazing to think of
Good idea
I take my wife out more. I enjoy seeing the money in my bank account not disappear as quickly!
Let myself spend money on fixing my teeth

#70: Research says that people who practice gratitude have greater peace of mind, happiness, physical health, and deeper, more satisfying personal relationships. Try taking 5 minutes today to write down what you're grateful for and post what you appreciated here. #reinforcement
I am grateful right now for my boyfriend and his daughter. For showing me I'm worth it and what love really is.
My job and fsmily
New job, new house, freedom from smoking, etc.

#67: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I had my car detailed; it smelled like new and really made me not want to smoke in it anymore!" Would cleaning your car motivate you to stay quit? Tell us why (or why not). #reinforcement

I completely cleaned my car and no longer smoke in it. Very helpful method.
Yes that's a really good idea
Yes
#66: If you're tired, hungry, or cranky, taking just five minutes to refresh yourself with water or a snack can make all the difference. Tell us how you plan to refresh yourself today! #reinforcement
I'll try this with fruits and apple juice
I get Starbucks. Coffee is nectar of the gods.

#65: Many new quitters put on a few pounds because of the metabolism-shock. Keeping healthy snacks on hand can help you keep your weight under control. What’s your favorite healthy snack or recipe? #feelinghealthy

Strawberries!
Fruit and granola bars!?!  Yummy

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Getting Ready to Quit 6.
data.name: Session 6 - Smoking cessation advice
data.caption: Session 6 - Smoking cessation advice
data.description: This week I will hold the last of our special smoking cessation advice sessions. We will review some of the most important tips to quit smoking and will talk about how to maintain long-term motivation to stay smoke-free. Hope to see you guys there!

data.message: Hi everyone, I am ready to start with our last smoking cessation advice session 6. Today we will review the most important tips to quit smoking and talk about long-term motivation to stay smoke-free. Feel free to stop by!
Guys, check out the content of this last session on the wall of this event. I'll see you next week for the next "The Doctor Is In" session. Have a great week!
Have you ever tried to quit or reduce your smoking? Which strategy did you choose and how did it go? #TDII
I stopped smoking in my car and pushed my first cigarette of the day back about 2 hours.
Hi 10283 - and how did it go?
Went well. Not smoking right when I woke up made a huge difference.
Are you still smoke free right now? Any difficult situations that came up since your quit day?
Still smoke free! I've had a few stressful situations at work, but I just stepped away for a few minutes to collect myself.
Really cool 10283 - you can be proud of yourself! Have you already noticed any positive changes since you quit? How are you feeling?
I sleep a lot better now. And my sense of smells seems to be returning!
That sounds about right - I'll also repost this chart of benefits after quitting so you can check out what other cool things you can look forward to and stay motivated :)
I'm vaping now and it's wonderful. No cigarettes for me.
I'm glad to hear it's still working out for you 10261! You know my take on e-cigs/vapes and that I can't support them 100%, but if they got you to stop smoking I think that's a great thing!

10261 - do you ever crave smoking cigarettes at all anymore? How often do you use your vape pen on an average day and which nicotine concentration works best for you? I'm trying to learn more about vaping and how it can work for smoking cessation.
Johannes Thrul I am not even craving cigarettes. The smell and taste completely makes me gag now. I started on 6mg and I'm down to 3mg. I'll probably go down to 1.5mg then go to 0.
That sounds great - so tapering down is what you would recommend?
I mainly use my vape when I'm stressed but I'm doing better and can use it less and is so much easier to go without it.
I would taper down. I know people that went right to no nicotine then broke the habit

Interesting - so it sounds like for you it was really the combination of lowering the nicotine dose and also trying to break the habit of using it in certain situations. What do you do in those stressful situations now instead?
I normally just go to the gym at this point. I don't feel the need to run to smoking.

It sounds like you are well on your way to becoming totally nicotine free then! I think that's great! Keep up the good work and let me know if you have any specific questions or encounter difficult situations. And thanks for sharing your experiences with me - very interesting :)
#64: When you're a nonsmoker, what will be different about your daily life? Tell us what you're looking forward to! #knowyourself
No need to constantly take breaks. Uninterrupted projects.
Healthier and better life. More money in my pocket
I agree with 10261 and 10285. More money, less interruptions and overall higher quality of life.
Not waking up with a raspy voice

#63: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I bought myself a new CD for each week that I stayed smoke-free." Do you feel like your iTunes collection could use some new editions? #reinforcement
Nail Polish
I'll buy more stuff for my house as I stay tobacco free.
Car parts and baby stuff! Plus, more dates with my wife.
More bill money!

Yeah, I hear you 10283 - we've all been there. What else have you tried to cope when you are sitting in traffic and how did it go?
Boredom.
Hi 10215 - have you experimented with alternatives other than smoking a cig that can help to deal with boredom?
Usually I just honk at people. Haha. I stopped smoking in my car; had it detailed and everything.
That's great to hear 10283 - way to go! How do you feel about your quit day? Are you still committed to becoming smoke free?
Usually I let myself snack but I've tried not to do that either so I'm unsure what else to try. I'm usually pretty busy so I'm keeping up with that trying to stay busy.
I've pretty much quit already. I've only had 1 since Monday evening.
Very cool 10283! So you've been almost smoke free for 2 days already! How will you be getting rid of these last cigarettes?
I have 3 or 4 left in my pack so I'll make sure those are gone by the night before my quit date and follow the steps recommended by you and this group!

Sound great 10283 - I'm very proud of you and you should be well prepared for your quit day. Feel free to reach out if there is anything else we can help you with. Remind yourself of your most important reasons and keep practicing the strategies you have learned to overcome the urges. You can do it!!
Thanks, Johannes Thrul!
Anger, hunger, and boredom

#59: Very soon, you'll need something new to turn to when you're stressed out. Have you built up your social support team enough to have someone to call if you need advice? Who are you planning to reach out to? Why them? #control

I have some of the best friends a girl could ask for. Almost no one in my circle smokes so I'm on a good path.
My mom and coworkers. The two biggest supporters
My mom and my fiancé are the best supporters I have

#11: Now that you’ve shared about your top reasons for quitting, let’s consider your top reason NOT to quit. Post your #1 Con for quitting and tell us why it’s your biggest concern. You can finish this sentence: "I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that ________."Feel free to discuss with other group members your concerns about quitting. #freeyourself
I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that when I get stressed out I will start drinking.
Letting go of my security blanket
^security blanket, same as 10257.
I third security blanket

#3: Have any of you used a quit program or counseling program before? There are lots of free programs out there- how could they benefit you? What would make them better? #beingconscious
I haven't used one yet but I'd like to if proven beneficial. Talking to someone seems like it would be counter productive though I would just want it off my mind
I have tried the various phone apps available but it is very easy to hit the ignore button/uninstall when you're the only one that knows about it.
I had to take a smoking cessation course in high school. Good info but I didn't want to quit at the time!
I had a cessation class in high school. I've tried nicotine replacement products and medicines.
Thanks for sharing!
Yes
#4: Take this test to see how addicted to nicotine you are. What’s your reaction to your score? Are you surprised? #beingconscious http://www.nova.edu/gsc/nicotine_risk.html
I got low dependency and I'm not surprised. I've always been "okay" at quitting I just pick it back up real easily.
I got an eight. Not surprised.
I got a 5!
Mine was 2 so I'm feeling pretty happy about that
I got a one... that doesn't feel right.
Thanks for giving the test a try! Remember, this test is just one way to assess your nicotine dependence, and may or may not be accurate to you.

#13: Asking you to go out and party, even though they know drinking is a trigger, would NOT be helpful. Joking about how long you’ll stay on the quit wagon would NOT be helpful. What other things could you ask your friends NOT to do to keep you on the right path? #support

Not talk to me. Haha. Almost all my friends smoke and I made the decision to end/put a hold on socializing with them to benefit my health.
Remind me of the health benefits everyday
Not smoke in front of me.
All of the above. Don't smoke before they see me because the smell will be on their clothes
#16: What do you know about the patch as a type of Nicotine Replacement Therapy? Have/would you ever use it? #beingconscious
Cons: allergies Can be severe
Never used one. I don't like the idea of absorbing nicotine through my skin haha.
Never used one. Haven't heard to much about it. I don't think I would ever use it
Thanks for sharing!
It broke me out

#18: This over-the-counter Nicotine Replacement Therapy looks like cough drops and can help alleviate withdrawal symptoms during work or class. Would you try this method? Why or why not? #beingconscious
I tried them years ago. They treated terrible and made me sick
I think using nicotine replacement after quitting is somewhat counter-productive because you haven't truly quit until you're nicotine free. In my opinion.
So no I don't think I'd do that haha.
I might try this depending on how much I was smoking and if I was extremely addicted smoking over a pack a day and then quit cold turkey
Thank you for sharing!
They are nasty!

#33: Having a phrase or mantra that’s motivating and centering that you can repeat to yourself when things get tough can be a HUGE help to deal with cravings. Think of your own mantra or phrase and post it here. #feelinghealthy
It is what it is

I'm stronger than this.
Can't say it on here, sorry

How does your smoking affect your loved ones, kids, or significant other? What do they think about your smoking? #TDII

My wife has been trying to get me to quit for years. She's been pushing a lot harder since she got pregnant (I don't smoke around her). She's not a fan of the financial burden it causes as well as the health risks smoking causes!
Thanks for sharing 10283 - sounds like she can potentially be a strong motivator for you (and your baby as well of course). How are your preparing for your quit day and how is that going?

I'm actually starting a new job around my quit date and also starting to switch up my morning routine to avoid smoking until about 10am. I would normally have my first cigarette at 7am. I think adjusting my routine is becoming quite helpful.
I absolutely agree - it's all about breaking free of those old habits. Have you though about or tried any of the alternatives to smoking we discussed last week?
I've started playing a game on my phone when I have cravings but I'm having trouble with finding a game that holds my attention.
Haha fair enough. Has playing helped at all while you were at it though?
I think it has. It's helped me push off more than a few cigarettes! Candy crush is only fun for so long haha.
Agreed 10283 - unfortunately I'm not much of a gamer so I don't have any good recommendations. Maybe some of the other group members do? How confident do you feel that you can quit on your quit day?
Neither am I, which is why I've been struggling! I'm extremely confident.
That's great to hear! How many cigs a day do you smoke at the moment?
10-12, down from 20 a week ago.
My fiance hates it! The money spent and my health
That's pretty good already, great job! Have you thought about nicotine trying nicotine replacement at all?
Thought about it, just can't afford it.
10285 thanks for sharing! How can your finance support you in quitting smoking?
10283, which state do you live in? There may be options to get it for free. Also keep in mind, those cigarettes aren't free either :)
My whole family smokes. So I'm the odd one out
I'm in Utah. I'll look in to that!
Keep up the good work 10261! How are you holding up?
Holding up just fine. This is the only "nicotine replacement" I've used and worked. No cravings. Nothing. I feel great and I'm only using 3mg
10283 - check out the Smokers quit line. They can hook you up with free Nicotine replacement http://waytoquit.org/free-quit-services/ Do you think you will give them a call?

Glad to hear it 10261! I recommend you try to switch things up in terms of the situations you use your vape in. Because a big part of quitting smoking is unlearning all the situational triggers - so try to not use it in the same situations in which you smoked before.

Great, I'll check in with you next week! I've got to run. See you guys!
I haven't been. I really only use it to stop myself from smoking. Its nice.

data.name: Session 1 - Smoking cessation advice
data.caption: Session 1 - Smoking cessation advice
data.description: Hi everyone, this week I will be starting with our special sessions to give you even more support and extra tips to quit smoking! We have designed a total of 6 sessions and each one will last approximately 45 minutes. In these sessions, I will work with each of you to come up with your own specific quit plan. Attending these will really increase your chances of quitting (if you desire to do so). All of this is going to happen on the wall of this event and I look forward to seeing you there! Please let me know if you have any questions.

data.message: I am ready to start with the first smoking cessation advice session. Attending these will really increase your chances of quitting tobacco (if you desire to do so), so feel free to stop by.
I have posted the content of today's session on the wall of this event - check it out if you're interested. See you next week!

Since you told us at the beginning you are ready to quit smoking, I was wondering if anyone of you may be ready to set a quit date? (Experts agree this is the most effective way to quit for good). If you already have one, how are you preparing for it? #TDII
I've cut back on how much I smoke. I've tried to make it less important when it comes to my daily routine. I'm hoping to be done for good by the end of July!
That's really cool, 10215! What strategies are you using to reduce your smoking and how are they working out for you?

I'm keeping myself busy and coming up with new hobbies. If I'm busy I don't think about smoking as much. That and I have asked my friends not to ask me to go out and smoke or talk about it. I've also stayed away from triggers like going out for drinks. At least until I've quit completly
10215 that sounds great - you are already taking some of the most important steps and it sounds like they are working! What are the situations where it is still hard for you to not smoke?

I feel like it's been working so far. Better than it has before. It's still hard not to smoke when I wake up and drive to work. I still feel like it wakes me up..starts my day off I'm just use to it still I guess.
Glad to hear it's working well overall. What else could you do in the morning to start off your day other than smoking?
Drink more water possibly might help

Taking a shower first thing or brushing your teeth may help too. If you have a fresh taste in your mouth smoking may be less appealing. Also gum, mints, or something else to chew on like toothpicks may help. What do you think?
Sorry I've got to run. Check out the first smoking cessation advice session tomorrow if you're interested. See you!

#28: Ready to commit to quitting? If yes, pick a date to quit smoking for good! Post it here, or create a group event and invite everyone in this group. Everytime you check Facebook, you’ll be reminded that someone is making the change with you. #freeyourself
I think I'm going to buy my vaping stuff this week and Friday will be the last day for me.
I haven't decide on an exact date yet but my goal is in 6 months
Every time I set a date, my life gets evermore complicated
July 25th

I have tried them. They take off the edge for me
Exact same as 10285 they take the edge off for me but I can't get myself to stop when I try them

I haven't heard of it which scares me. But my response will be exactly the same as yesterday. I feel like I'm not fully informed. I need to know if the risks outweigh the benefits. What are the side effects, the negatives, the risks? Will it be like chantix where I went bat shit insane?
I have not heard of it. I prefer not to take prescriptions. It takes money to go to the doctor just to be prescribed medicine. No thanks.
A friend of mine took this and succesfully quit. He would vomit if he was near cigarette smoke so I guess that's one way to do it haha but I'm not a fan of meds.
I would most likely try it. I would read up on it tho and stop taking it if I had any bad side effects

I've done some preliminary research on this. Doesn't sound as bad as others that I've heard of.  Sounds like a great antidepressant as well. I'm not really into meds but I'm definitely killing myself while smoking so it might come to something like this for me
Thank you so much for sharing!

About a 5
7 or 8
5 for me

I think self-help guides work best for me because I like to understand the basis of why people do the things they do.
Great chart. I feel like the quit smoking business is just as expensive as smoking.
I agree with 10261 and 10283. The companies know that nicotine is addicting so why not make a profit trying to help the ppl that want to quit. They know they would make a lot of money
Medication pills. I would remember how bad cigarettes are for me everytime I took the pill and not wanting to take the pill anymore would make me want to stay quit
What would you miss most if you quit smoking for good? #TDII

I'd miss having a crutch to fall back on in times of turmoil, socially smoking, and that's about it. Haha. I would NOT miss the financial burden, odor, and disappearing every 45 minutes for a smoke when I have important things to do.
Thanks for sharing 10283 - you also already answered my next question ;) Sounds like you have plenty of reasons for wanting to quit. What's your current smoking status?
My main reason is a baby girl coming in September! I smoke a pack a day during the work week and like 5 on days when I'm not working. Needless to say, my job stresses me out haha.
10283 have you already though about which strategies to quit/reduce smoking could work for you?
btw: Your baby girl is a great reason for wanting to quit!!

I'm reading Allen Carr's EASYWAY To Quit Smoking. You're probably familiar with that book, it addresses the psychology side of smoking. I'm essentially trying to retrain my brain to go to feeling free from smoking vs missing everything about it.
That's great 10283! Have you given any though to deciding on a quit date yet?
I haven't yet because the book says not to until you've finished reading it. But, I have an unofficial quit date of 7/24/15.
Ok great, that will also give us some time to prepare your quit date here at TSP if you'd like! Have you talked to friends and family about your plans to quit?
What steps do you suggest taking to succeed in quitting? The first obviously being a quit date. Yes, my friends and family are supportive of my decision to quit. My mother actually gave me EASYWAY.

You are already right on track with your quite date and telling friends and family - these are important steps. In the next weeks we will work on other important things like identifying your high risk situations and coming up with alternatives to smoking. Have you given any though to nicotine replacement therapy? Is this something you may be interested in?

I've given it some thought but I'm pretty opposed to meds because for work, I deal with FDA regulations and whatnot and understand how easy it is to put nasty stuff in pharma drugs, dietary/nutritional supplements, etc. Which worries me haha.

Ok, I understand. It's of course totally up to you what you want to try - I'll support you either way! NRT can be useful for helping with withdrawal and craving, but you can also make it work without NRT, for sure! One more thing we'll work on over the next weeks is relapse prevention.
I'll miss my crutch. I'm socially awkward. It's my get away fast ticket.
Yeah, relapses are my biggest worry!
10261 - thanks for sharing! And what are the things about smoking you would be happy to get rid of?
10283 - ok, I see. We will work on that as well!
Sorry guys, I've got to run. Great session today! I'll check in with you next week. See ya!
Just about everything. I can't stand it.
Thanks, Johannes Thrul!
I would miss a lot that's for sure lol I honestly enjoy smoking I wish it wasn't so bad for my health
#21: How do you feel about this medication that changes its dose of nicotine to match the intensity of your withdrawal symptoms? Would any of you consider using varenicline? #beingconscious
I feel like I'm not fully informed. I need to know if the risks outweigh the benefits. What are the side effects, the negatives, the risks? Will it be like chantix where I went bat shit insane?

Yeah I'd want to see the studies done on any drug used for smokers. Active ingredients are important. I do quality management for a dietary supplement company so I know how easy it is to manipulate pharma labels. Data, baby!
I second what 10261 and 10283 said. Besides I don't want to go to the doctor to get a  prescription. It's expensive
I don't think I would try to use this either due to uncertainty
These are great points! Feel free to bring up any questions about NRT's in our TDII sessions! :)

#20: When withdrawal symptoms are at their worst, a nasal spray can be a quick and convenient way to pack a punch to those cravings. Would you ever use a nicotine nasal spray? Why or why not? #beingconscious
Not in my nose. Nope. I hate nasal sprays.
I second what 10261 said lol
I third 10261's comment haha. I bet the "drip" in the back of your throat would taste quite bad.

I have allergies, this won't do.  It's worth mentioning the cost efficient of these methods as that is a major factor in choice. I've never heard of this method before and I wouldn't know how much it cost. Do you have to go through a doctor? I don't have med insurance because I'm still smoking and it's already expensive enough
I agree with 10261, 10283, and 10257
Thanks for discussing, everyone!

data.message: #19: Would you consider using a nicotine inhaler to quit smoking? Why or why not? #beingconscious
This may help a lot because it's really similar to puffing on a cigarette
It sounds similar to vaping. Which I want to try. It would be a consideration
Depends on the active ingredients!
This sounds very interesting. I would definitely try this
Thanks for sharing, everyone!
#17: What have you heard about nicotine gum? Do you think you’d try it? #beingconscious
I've heard the flavor of various nicotine gums is awful. That being said, I'm not a huge fan of chewing gum anyway so I don't think this is a viable option for me personally.
I've tried it. It was terrible.
I've tried it and I hated it. It made me so sick
No, I would not try it for two reasons oneI'm not the best at chewing gum. For some reason I chew for about 30 seconds and then swallow the gum. My second I heard it tastes terrible

Hi Everyone, I am switching things up and doing The Doctor Is In a bit later this week. What are people dealing with this week? Has anyone in this group tried to quit smoking? If so, how did it go? If not, what is getting in your way?

I've not tried. on my next day off, I plan to draw up a sleep/eating/workout schedule to help reduce stress when I go cold turkey. I'm gonna write these things down on paper because I've read that the act of writing things down significantly increases the chance of success
I'm planning on vaping.

Good ideas, 10257! Making a plan definitely does increase chances of success. Other strategies that tend to work well are to tell people in your life you are planing to quit and to get rid of smoking paraphernalia as the quit date gets closer. Do you think those could work for you?
I don't think throwing a lighter away will help. There's always one available

Using an e-cig or other gaping product is a strategy that does work for some people, altho the research is generally showing that it may not be as good as nicotine replacement therapy or medication. Have you tried gaping before, 10261?

10257, I definitely appreciate that concern, but if the lighter in not next to you, it is slightly harder to get and your craving may have passed by the tie you can go buy one. That's all you need to do is get through the craving...
If I don't have smokes, then a lighter is equally nearby. Lol, not trying to be difficult
He's right tho. Where I live I can knock on my neighbors door or walk less than a block.
I tried vaping before. I was successful until my battery died at my grandfather's funeral. Needless to say it was an end game at that point.

I definitely appreciate both of your points. But at least if you get rid of everything as much as you can it will be slightly harder (hopefully). If you guys are dealing with cravings that would make it hard not to smoke, in addition to getting rid of smoking paraphernalia (e.g., ashtrays) that can trigger you, medication or nicotine replacement therapy may help.

Personally medication is a no go. No no no no. I have too much going on mentally I will not take medication unless absolutely necessary. It's not fun when a medication has an ill side effect. Last time I tried to quit with meds it left me suicidal. Nope. Not at all. Nicotine replacement I've tried it all. Not once had it worked.

Ok, well you have to do what's right of you. You may want to quit with the help of your doctor, if possible. In the meantime, watch how vamping effects cravings to smoke. Could go either way. Feel free to share how it goes in this group. Do you have a quit date, 10261? What about you, 10257?
I go by the my body will tell me. Last time I just didn't want to smoke. In anticipating this time will be similar
I'll have a lot more details next week. I'm swamped at work but I'm off Friday
Ok guys, well good luck. 10257, if you set a date to stop smoking on Friday and share it with us, we can help you to make a plan and support you through it.
Sounds good
Just so you guys have it, we have a five step quit plan at TSP that we recommend people use as they are preparing to quit. Here goes:

1. GET READY.• Set a quit date and stick to it – not even a single puff! When do you think you will be ready?2. GET SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT.• Tell your family, friends and coworkers you are quitting.• Talk to your doctor or other health care provider.• Get group, individual, or telephone counseling. 3. LEARN NEW SKILLS AND BEHAVIORS.• When you first try to quit, change your routine.• Reduce stress.• Distract yourself from urges to smoke.• Plan something enjoyable to do every day.• Drink a lot of water and other fluids. 4. GET MEDICATION AND USE IT CORRECTLY.Talk with your health care provider about which medication will work best for you:• Medication: bupropion, verenicline (prescription).• Nicotine Replacement:-gum and patch are over-the-counter-inhaler and nasal spray are prescription5. BE PREPARED FOR RELAPSE OR DIFFICULT SITUATIONS.• Avoid alcohol.• Be careful around other smokers.• Improve your mood in ways other than smoking.• Eat a healthy diet and stay active.
Next week Johannes Thrul will be back. It has been a pleasure to do The Dr. Is In sessions these past few weeks, thanks, guys!
#15: Gradually reducing the amount you smoke can also lead to quitting. Do you think gradual reduction could be right for you? #beingconscious
In the long run. Probably best bet.
I think it helps if you write out a plan, tell no one, and document it. That way you can track your progress. Measurable goals.
It helps make quitting less stressful I think which would end up making it easier
I'm actually working on this plan at the moment. It helps if I just put my mind on something else when I start craving

#14: Historically, most successful quitters chose this approach. Learn about withdrawal symptoms and cravings at the link below and tell us if you plan to use this method. Why or why not? #beingconscious http://www.webmd.com/smoking-cessation/quit-smoking
I think I'm going to start vaping. I've tried everything else. I don't have much to lose.
I plan on using cold turkey. I think it will be the easiest way to quit believe it or not

I've had friends who have gone camping in a remote area for a week without tobacco and they came back nicotine-free. I've heard that works for some people. I recently started reading Allen Carr's EASYWAY book and it has helped me out a lot. He smoked 5 packs a day and then had an epiphany of sorts and quit.
I'm going to try that too 10261
Awesome. I've done it before and did pretty good.

data.message: #7: Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have started smoking at an earlier age if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig
It's a possibility. I think the ice-cream trucks that had those candy cigarettes had more of an impact.
It's hard to say. Vape rigs can be expensive whereas a single cig every now and again would be easy to obtain as a broke adolescent
I don't think so. Smoking appeal wasn't to do with the flavor when I was young.
It's difficult for me to say at this moment
No. It had nothing to do with flavor. I think it's a crock of shit that everyone thinks its aimed at children. Every shop I see where I am won't let you in if your under 18.
10261, if you've actually studied marketing, you'll find that a lot of things are marketed to children.
And your argument about not being allowed in under 18 is invalid given that a lot of us started smoking before 18
Thank you for sharing!

#6: For any of you who aren’t sure what e-cigs are, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing or “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious
data.name: Electronic Cigarettes (e-Cigarettes)
data.caption: www.fda.gov
data.description: Electronic cigarettes, also known as e-cigarettes, are battery-operated products designed to deliver nicotine, flavor and other chemicals. They turn chemicals, including highly addictive nicotine, into...

data.message: I watch allot of younger kids and most of them think the risk is about the same.
Safer is a convoluted word haha. I think they appear "cooler" than regular cigarrettes and definitely taste better but they have no real benefit other than a massive nicotine rush.
Unless whoever uses no nicotine. Because that is an option.
True. I think for a lot of people they just enjoy the habit so e-cigs may be a viable option.
I think they would consider it just as much as an actual cigarette. I don't think they would see it as more appealing but "just as" appealing for sure.

I vaped for 4 months last year and even quit smoking during that time. I also had a scratchy throat all the time. The vaping experts might tell you it's because my pg/vg  radio was off but still... I think it helped a little but I'm just such a one-track mind person that I probably vapid more nicotine in a day than smoked.
I think it's a good tool to temporarily help physically dependant smokers ween off nicotine, but it's not for everyone,  nor can it be considered safe given the lack of longterm research
Can it help me reduce smoking and finally just quit?
Probably. I've seen a bunch of people do it.
Thanks 10261
Thanks so much for discussing! :D

#12: When you’re quitting, your friends and family may be eager to help out in any way that they can. Pick your favorite option below or suggest your own. Why would this option be helpful to you? #support • Go places where smoking is not allowed• Send you daily/weekly words of encouragement• Quit smoking with you
Quit with me because I believe it takes a village
Lol I'll try. I got cussed at while at work today and I'm pretty sensitive to those sort of things
Either quit with me or don't pester me about quitting haha.
Quit with me
All of the family would help especially my partner
#10: What are your top reasons for quitting? #freeyourself
I want to quit to better my health and start a family one day.
Cancer. one ugly word. Many lives close to me taken or touched. Including my own.
Health. Future kids. Money
Money,  blood pressure,  and pride because I hate being slave to a little white stick
#9: Write a list of all the reasons why you want to quit, and post it somewhere prominent where you will frequently see it. Which spot did you choose, and why will it work for you? #reinforcement
I don't need to. Mine is tattooed on me. I remind myself daily.
That seems like a great way to help me with my daily struggles
In my car. I always chain smoke when I drive and I drive frequently. I do a lot of deep thinking when I drive as well
Rearview mirror in my car!

Since stress is coming up a lot today, I want to leave you guys with a post about visual imagery that can help if you are having cravings to smoke and don't want to (or can't). As an experiment this week, try this and see if it can be helpful to you.
Uh oh. I was super late.
Hi Everyone, I'm here for the next hour to answer any questions or chat about smoking and quitting. What have been your biggest triggers to smoke lately?
Hanging out with friends that smoke. Social gatherings. I'm not use to watching everyone else smoke and me not have my pack in my hand or lighting up myself
Social situations are huge triggers. Have you ever tried not smoking when you were around people who were smoking?
Work in general. I have a high-stress management position.
Stress is another very common trigger. What works for you to reduce or manage stress other than smoking?
In case anyone here is interested, here is a simple quiz we use in TSP that assesses your level of stress. https://ucsf.co1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_a4bsPIqLQjDxSrH
I work out daily and that helps but doesn't seem to be enough.

10283 that is a very good start! Exercise will definitely help, especially doing it when there is a time that you have a lot of cravings. Other strategies we recommend at TSP include using imagery. I'll post something here about it now.
Yes and it's quite difficult. I end up drinking a lot if I don't which leads to more smoking. Or I become less social. Which does help me quit.

I appreciate that challenge, 10215. That is why it is important to figure out a good stately for handling social situations when you quit. In the beginning, it may be necessary to stay away from alcohol (huge trigger) and maybe even some smoking friends if that's what you need to get through the first few days…best to figure out a plan that will work for you. Let us know if we can be helpful with this as you are making a plan to quit. Happy to help.
Keeping it on my mind that quitting is the best option helps a ton! Thanks for all the help you're giving us
I scored a 15 on the stress test.
That's probably my biggest obstacle toward not smoking

10283, here is an example of some guided visual imagery we recommend if stress is really getting to you. If you have an office, it's something you can do with the door closed, or even on a walk instead of smoking.
Thanks, Danielle! Is this one of those as-needed type of things or should I try to do this frequently?

These kinds of meditation principles can be used absolutely any time and you only need about 1-2 mins. When you are first quitting, I recommend using them often, in part because you may get lots of cravings. They can help you "surf the urge" to smoke. Riding it out for the 3-5 mins a craving lasts….then as your craving reduce you may be able to use it less often. Remind me how much you smoke now?
Sorry tons of typos there! Meant MEDITATION principals  - big difference between meditation and medication. In fact, medication may be helpful too, but that's not what this slide is talking about.
I smoke pretty much a pack a day. I'd like to avoid meds if possible!

Wow! I smoke 4 packs of cigarettes in 7 days! That's too much money
35,000 cigarettes in my life time! Wow.
I smoke at least 183 packs a year. That's insane.
I don't wanna know

data.message: #2: Why is quitting smoking important to you? Is there anything that would make it even more important? #motivation
Because I've had cancer once and I don't want it again. Not to mention I just lost 2 family members to cancer. #curecancer #cancersucks
First child due in 09/2015! The only thing that'd make it more important would be having twins haha
Health. I hate running out of breath. That an having a child is in my future and I. Don't want to set a bad example
I want to be around for future kids, grandkids, and their big accomplishments in life.
I want to be healthy and not struggle for oxygen every day

#5: Big tobacco companies aim to make their brand appealing. Become more conscious and learn to critique cigarette ads. In the ads below, how is Camel trying to manipulate its customers? #beingconscious
Sex. That girl.
What 10261 said! Haha
Ditto. Sex appeal
I dont know if they are marketing towards the whole sex appeal or if they're trying to get you to think it makes you look cooler.
#1: On a scale of 1-10, how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #motivation
10, but for some reason it seems like I don't care how important it is to me....
10, I know I need this

Hi Guys, welcome to TSP! In addition to daily posts, we also have weekly sessions with a live person who can talk to you about smoking and quitting. It's usually Johannes Thrul, but today you are getting me. I am an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at UCSF in San Francisco and creator of TSP. Happy to answer any questions you have - I'm here for an hour. Is anyone ready to set a quit date yet?
10261 had a glitch and missed your post. feel free to post again
No date but getting myself ready.
That's a good start! What do you need to become fully ready?
Just to wrap my head around it. I've been smoking for over 10 years.

That's a while, and it's never a bad time to quit. So whenever you're ready, we're here. Happy to support your wrapping. One suggestion (not that you asked necessarily) is to make a list of the reasons you may want to quit and also the reasons you do not want to quit. It's ok to recognize that there are reasons that it is hard...
Like extreme nicotine addiction. The withdrawal is terrifying.
Have you tried to quit before? What worked or did not work?
Just about everything. Its been a battle for 5ish years now.

Got it. Well good to hear you are still motivated to try again. That's the only way it will eventually work. If you are particularly afraid of withdrawals, you may want to consider nicotine replacement therapy (patch, gum, lozenge). Or medication (bupropion, verenicline). Have you tried any of these before?
I've quit on and off for 10 years now. After not smoking for 3 months it always surprises me how easy it is to start again. I never stop wanting them. No matter how long I quit.
Hi 10215, I appreciate that, and I've heard that from others as well. How have you need able to stay smoke free for 3 months? That's a while!

I picked up my first cigarette at 12-13 and started smoking consistently at about 15. I can quit completely on the weekend but once the work week starts, I smoke 10-15 a day. I have a daughter due in September and definitely want to quit before her birth. Thoughts?

I've tried replacments. I never stick with them because I still want to smoke. My psychiatrist doesn't want me on medicines. I started vaping. That's been the only thing that can keep me away for an extended period

Good stuff here, guys! 10283 a baby is definitely a good motivator. 10261, you might consider talking with a doctor about combining a few types of nicotine replacement (NRT) if you are still getting what we call "breakthrough urges" with only one form of NRT. For example, patch and gum. Don't want to recommend specific without knowing your specific situation but it is possible and works well for some people.

Cold turkey. No aides at all I just keep telling myself I can't have one. Then I'm out with friends and I have one thinking that's not so bad and I'm addicted again. It becomes a part of my daily routine so easily
My last option was chantix and absolutely not. Nope never. Not even an option. The side effects are devastating
I'm the same way when I quit 10215. As soon as I have 1 out with friends or whatever it's end of story.

For all of you guys, you have to find the strategies that are relevant to your own experience. So for example, in this groups, 10283, it will be important to use your baby to continue to motivate you. Remind yourself what a great dad you want to be if you have a craving, for example. 10215, if you are going out with friends, know that is a high risk situations for you and plan ahead if you don't want to smoke. Perhaps bring gum for the whole night or something like that. 10261 you have to find a good strategy for medication that will help you and it may be more useful to do so with your doctor.

Also, not to overwhelm you guys, but the best thing you can do to start the process of quitting is to set a date.  Then we can talk about what strategies can help you quit on that date. Is anyone here ready to set a date now?
Gotta run guys, but I will be here two more weeks and we can follow-up on any other issues you are thinking about before our regular counselor Johannes Thrul is back. Great chatting today!

I have quit a couple times. Last time was five months.  I had no social life as I knew I would feel the social urge to smoke. I got depressed, branched out for social interaction, ended up at my favorite bar and continued the habit. I know I can do this, but where to direct my energy?

data.message: Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! Thank you for joining us -- we're so excited to have you here. We will share our first post in just a FEW MINUTES! Here's how it works:1) We will share one post everyday for 90 days. Remember to turn on Notifications (top right corner) and check this page daily!2) Your group has been randomly assigned to a Weekly Incentive. To earn money, you must comment on ALL posts we share each week. You will earn $7 if you've commented on all 7 posts, and $0 if you comment on 6 or less. We'll tally your comments every week, and you'll have a new chance to earn money at the start of the next week. You will receive a gift card for the money you've earned at the end of the 90-day program.3) Dr. Danielle Ramo will be joining us for 1 hour each week, for the first 3 weeks, during which she will answer any tobacco-related questions, share info and resources, and provide support to our group. Stay tuned for her first session TODAY at 4pm! After the first 3 weeks, Dr. Johannes Thrul will be taking over the sessions.
Sweet
Sounds good!

This group is for 18-25 year olds who currently smoke and are ready to quit in the very near future. While your quit-date approaches, get educated about Nicotine Replacement Therapies, ways to prepare for and deal with cravings & triggers, grow your support system and learn the best techniques to quit and STAY quit. This group has been randomly selected to have Weekly Incentives; you can accumulate $7 at the end of every week in which you comment every day, for a gift card of up to $90 at the end of the session.

data.message: Hi guys, I am getting ready to start with session 3. Stop by if you want to learn about social support and quitting.
Feel free to check out today's session if you're interested! See you next week.
My family is helping me out a lot

That’s it for today’s session.Between now and next time, practice being assertive. You can do it!Also, keep commenting on your Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities. Use this Pleasant Activities checklist to identify some activities that interest you. See you next time! Bye.

Sometimes you may have to respond by revealing to others how their behavior/comments make you feel. There are 3 steps to being successful with this: 1. Be neutral when describing their behavior to them2. Use “I feel” statements to describe how you feel about their comments/behavior3. Let them know what you want from them (i.e. a specific behavior change) that can help you as you quit  How do you think you could use these 3 steps in your situations to respond assertively?

Although other people may not always change their behavior upon your request, using these steps gives you a better chance of getting what you want and will leave you feeling better about yourself and your ability to be assertive.
Everyone is not the same personality. There are many personal styles of communicating:First is the passive style. Here’s a list:
Next there’s the aggressive style:
There’s one last personality type—the ASSERTIVE type:

By being assertive, you have the best chance of getting what you want and you will feel better about yourself by stating/responding that way.BUT…being assertive does not mean that you always have to speak your mind in every situation.Are there any situations in your pursuit of quitting smoking where you guys would like to be more assertive?

How would you handle the following situations without smoking?2. You just got out of school. A bunch of your friends are hanging out on the side of the school.You watch as someone in the group pulls out a pack of your favorite cigarettes and lights up.You smell the smoke and think about how you always used to enjoy a cigarette after school.Your friend notices that you’re looking at the cigarette, holds out the pack says, “Want one?”What would you do or say?

How would you handle the following situations without smoking 1. You’re at a party with a group of friends. Your friends are smoking.You’re feeling relaxed and thinking about how you always used to smoke at parties.Just as you start to say to yourself, “A cigarette would sure be good now,” your friend offers you a cigarette.What would you do or say?

Think positively about your decision to refuse a cigarette. It is easy to go along with what everyone else is doing.You are someone who makes a decision to do something and sticks to it!Respect yourself, and you will earn the respect of others in the long run.Here’s a pic you can use to remind you of the tips
Here’s another tip: Respond confidently.

One of the biggest challenges for an ex-smoker is declining a cigarette offer. Developing and practicing effective ways to turn down cigarette offers will reduce the chances of getting caught off guard.What are some situations where you might be offered a cigarette?

Anticipating these things is the first step to effectively turning down a cigarette offer. The next step is to respond effectively.What are some things you could say in response to an offer in the situations you mentioned?
Today I thought I could talk a bit about "support" and quitting. Who is supportive about you quitting?
What are some things others can do that would be helpful to you while you become smoke-free? What can you ask them to do to support you?
What are some things others can do that would NOT be helpful/hinder your quitting?And how can you ask your supporters to stop doing these unhelpful things?
What triggers led you to smoke this week? What was your mood? Who were you with?
What do you think you can do differently next time you’re in a similar situation?
How did you use your mood log this week?
How many cigarettes did you smoke this week on average (if any), number of pleasant activities, and your general mood? If you didn’t keep track, use your best guess.
Welcome to the third session. How has it been for you this week? When was the last time you smoked?

data.message: Hi everyone, I am about to start with session 4. Stop by if you want to learn about stress reduction and pleasant activities to help you quit smoking.
Feel free to check out the content of today's session on the wall of this event!
I am trying yoga and meditation

That’s it for today’s session.  Before we meet next time, practice imagery and deep breathing to help with your stress. Also, keep your “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” log up-to-date.
Did you do any interesting pleasant activities this week?If you had trouble, what got in the way?How can you add more pleasant activities into your schedule?

Have you tried deep breathing relaxation before?This is one of the simplest relaxation methods, based upon a meditative, deep-breathing technique. And just like any other skill; practice makes perfect!Here’s how you do it:

Many people find it helpful to mentally practice coping with high risk situations so they will be ready to deal with the real situation when it occurs.What scenarios do you think would be helpful to practice?

One scenario to practice if you are working on ways to refuse offers of cigarettes from others is to picture yourself assertively refusing a cig, and imagining yourself feeling relaxed while talking to your friends at a party (without smoking).With practice, imagery can be a powerful tool!

Imagery can remind yourself of why you are quitting smoking too, which can be really helpful when you’re in a high risk situation. You can picture the negative things that smoking causes and the positive things that quitting brings.What would you picture if you were craving a cigarette?
Here’s some tips to using imagery to help with cravings:
Do you think you would use and of these? If so, which ones?
Today I am going to discuss 2 simple techniques for relieving stress. Do you get stressed often? One technique is imagery. Imagery means picturing or imagining something in your mind.

Imagery can work as a stress reliever. Find somewhere quiet where you can be alone. Visualize a scene that makes you feel more relaxed. Then, focus on your senses (what do you see? Hear? Smell? Taste? Feel against your skin?)What scene would you imagine to relieve stress? Mine is usually standing on a mountain slope, breathing the crisp air and enjoying the spectacular view. Maybe Yosemite…
Here are some other ideas just for fun.
First, I want you guys to complete this Simple Stress and Tension self-test: STOP WHEN YOU CAN SEE YOUR RESULTShttps://ucsf.co1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_a4bsPIqLQjDxSrHWhat score did you get?
If you scored 12 or higher, that marks a high tension level and difficulty coping with the stress. Does this fit with how you see yourself right now?

Welcome to session 4.How did your “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” log  go this week? How many cigarettes did you smoked (if any)? The number of pleasant activities? Your general mood?

data.message: Hi everyone, I am getting ready to start with session 5. Today we will discuss weight gain after smoking cessation, exercise, healthy eating, and alcohol use.
Hi guys - I have posted to content of today's session on the wall of this event. Feel free to check it out!
Are you thinking about starting to exercise? If so, what is your goal?
Here are some tips with starting a new exercise program:
How do you plan to track your exercise and how will you reward yourself?

If you are having difficulties meeting your exercise program goals, you may want to stop and examine what you might be telling yourself. Here are some things people may say to talk themselves out of following through on their exercise plans:
I'm already weight lifting. I think working out makes me want to smoke less!
Any thoughts or questions about exercise and quitting smoking?
I started lifting in the morning and that helped me stop smoking right when I wake up.
That's great 10283 - you really made good use of exercising!
Lifting helped me cut down in the past so I figured I should try it again!
Alright, that’s it for today’s session. Keep using your “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” log.Good luck for your quit day 10283!! Keep up the good work!See you next week! Bye.

Another issue is around 'Thoughts on Alcohol and Drug Use'.Beyond considering how your drinking or drug use may interfere with your goal of quitting smoking, it is important to consider some of the effects of drinking or drug use on your life in general.Here are some questions you can ask yourself:
Do you have any questions or concerns about drinking and quitting smoking, so far?

Another important issue around quitting smoking is #3: Alcohol and Drug Use: Big-Time Triggers for SmokingFor most smokers, where they drink or do drugs they will also smoke. If your goal is to quit smoking, you should think very seriously about how you will deal with situations where you might drink alcohol or use drugs.What are your options?

• Option 1 Try not to smoke cigarettes in a situation where you are drinking or using drugs.• Option 2Avoid alcohol or drug use as a means of being successful at achieving your goal of quitting smoking.

If you choose Option 1:You should be prepared with several strategies for avoiding smoking.Some people try using substitutes for cigarettes, practice assertive ways to say no to cigarette offers and are ready with an escape plan or avoid groups that are smoking.If you choose Option 2:You can either…• Avoid alcohol and drug use until you feel confident that you can successfully not smoke in those situations or• Make changes in your alcohol and drug use behavior.How successful do you think you would be with Option 1?

It may turn out that this is the most difficult part of quitting smoking. You may realize that the extent of your drinking and/or drug use is a problem also.What strategies do you think will work well around drinking?

Here is a word of caution though:If your goal is to quit smoking and you decide that you will not be able to resist smoking when you are drinking or using drugs, then seriously consider Option 2.Any thoughts here?

We all come in different shapes and sizes. In our society, TV and other media tend to portray an extremely thin body as the ideal body type.  However, it is not realistic or healthy for everyone to look that way. A more realistic goal is to have a fit body, no matter your body type. By choosing to quit smoking, you are making a healthy lifestyle choice. You are choosing to be a strong, fit and healthy person.

Another important issue around weight gain and quitting is #2: making HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES. Knowledge about healthy food choices is helpful to new quitters because:• Ex-smokers tend to eat more sugary foods than they did while smoking.• Increased sugar can produce mood swings and can “sap” one’s energy.• Food often tastes and smells better when someone has quit smoking.• Some people use food as a substitute for tobacco when they try to quit.Does any of this apply to any of you?

Another issue is around 'How much is TOO MUCH?' Keeping a balance between the calories you take in and the calories you burn each day is the key to weight control.To determine the number of calories you need to maintain your current weight, use the following link:http://www.cancer.org/healthy/toolsandcalculators/calculators/app/calorie-counter-calculatorGo ahead and calculate this now. How does this number compare to what you had in mind?
You can also make healthier choices by paying attention to what you eat…..
What do you think would be practical for you in this area? What would be challenging?

Some people start out too fast or exercise too much and burn out after thinking about keeping up a regular exercise routine if they don’t already exercise regularly. Keep these things in mind:1. Start Gradually2. Set limited goals.For example:Week 1 = exercise 10 minutes every other day.Week 2 = add 5 minutes to your exercise time.Week 3 = add another 5 minutes to your exercise time.3.  Give yourself a one-month trial period.During the first few weeks, you should expect some initial discomfort while you gain strength and endurance. 4.  Be aware that achieving a high level of fitness after being out of shape takes about 3 to 4 months.

During this session, I’d like you to think about one goal you’ll set for yourself this week. First we are going to talk about an important issue around quitting smoking: Body weight concerns. Any reaction to this topic off the bat?

As you quit smoking, you may be concerned about possible weight gain, but KEEP IN MIND: there are lots of things you can do to prevent this from happening.#1: EXERCISE (which can be particularly helpful to you as you quit smoking). Here’s how exercise can help you quit:
What are some of your favorite ways to exercise?
Here are more ways that exercise can help with not smoking:
Which of these do you think would help you the most?

Welcome to session 5.Did you comment on your “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” log?How many cigarettes you smoked (if any), number of pleasant activities, and your general mood? If you didn’t keep track, take your best guess.
Haven't kept track but I usually only have one per day. A few pleasant activities, probably 2 per day. My general mood has been content with life!
What triggers led you to smoke? How did you feel at that time? Where were you and who were you with?
People being stupid pushed me to smoke. I felt disappointed I was smoking! I was usually alone in my car.
It's understandable that an upsetting situation would trigger urges for smoking. How would you cope with a situation like this after your quit day? What could you do instead?
I'd just try to ignore it and listen to music!

Sounds good. You should also remind yourself that cravings usually get a lot better after a few minuted like 2-5 and how disappointed you felt when you smoked last time. Cigarettes don't really reduce the stress level, but only feed your addiction. Do you think these strategies may help?
I think they would definitely help.
Great!

data.message: What from your experience is the best way to stay quit once you quit for good and is it worse on you to quit and then start over and over again or just continuously still smoke but smoke less ?
I want to know the same as 10215
Have you yourself smoked/successfully quit?

Hi 10215 and 10285 - yes, I have a couple of thoughts on the issue: There are certainly different ways to go about it. In my experience the best approach is to keep trying to quit completely! The problem with continuing to smoke a reduced number of cigs is that many smokers will kind of compensate by inhaling deeper, for example. And this unfortunately does not reduce the negative health effects very much. What you want to do and how you want to do it is totally up to you, but I'd be happy to support you either way to reach your goal!

10283 - yes, I also smoked when I was younger. However, I never smoked heavily because I have allergies etc., so my lungs gave me pretty immediate feedback that it was not good for me. Not being able to breath properly is a terrible feeling, but the good thing is that it made me quit!
Thanks Johannes Thrul. I really want to quit smoking and depending on cigarettes to make me feel better in stressful situations. My pockets can't take it anymore and I want to have a child soon

data.message: Best advice for succesfully quitting by the quit date I've set? 7/25/2015.

Hi 10283. Great, you have already set a quit date, which is the first important step. Additional steps are 2. Get support from family/friends/colleagues. 3. Learn new skills and alternative behaviors for your high risk situations. 4. Depending on how much you smoke, I would definitely recommend that you consider trying some form of nicotine replacement therapy – we know that using these can dramatically decrease your cravings and withdrawal and increase your chances to quit for good. 5. Be prepared for relapse or difficult situations (e.g., alcohol, being around other smokers, stress, etc.). I know this sounds like a lot, but we will cover each of these aspects more in depth over the next weeks (please check out the smoking cessation advice session I'll start tomorrow). How does this sound? Anything there you think may be useful?
I think all 5 recommendations are very useful. I think my biggest hurdle would be finding an alternative to smoking while at work.
Yes, that's a concern many of the people I work with have. What do you do at work? And what kind of alternatives can you think of that may work for you?
I run the QA/QC department for a manufacturing company. All I can think of is to eat instead of smoke. I have high metabolism so weight gain isn't a worry.

Some alternative you could try: Things that keep your hands busy - like playing a game on your phone for example. Or you could try gum, mints, chew on toothpicks, or other healthy snacks for example. Is smoking with your co-workers in breaks an issue for you?

I've made it a point to smoke alone, makes my job easier. Here's the thing, the FDA doesn't allow food in the environment I work in. I can only eat in my office or breakroom which is where I reside like 10% of the time I'm working. I could try downloading a game; that's a good idea.

Sure, just give it a try - it can't hurt right? Other options to keep your hands busy may be a stress ball or something like that, or you could start playing with a Rubik's cube if you are interested in solving puzzles :)
I will certainly give that a try. Thanks, Johannes!

data.message: From all of us at TSP, GOOD LUCK TO YOU 10215! We are so proud of your decision to quit and hope you stick you it. Please let us know if you need ANY help. Stay strong and think positive. You can do it!
Thank you :) I haven't had a cigarette since Tuesday and still haven't had one. Been brushing my teeth 4 times a day! Lol
Remember what you are gaining by quitting.
The night before your Quit Day, make sure you've gotten rid of all your cigarettes, lighters, matches and ashtrays from your car and home.

The night before your Quit Day, put together a non-smoker survival kit, complete with sugarless gum/candy, toothpicks, other substitutes for smoking, a list of your reasons for quitting, and phone numbers/photos of your support people.
The night before your Quit Day, reflect on the fact that tomorrow will be your first day free from cigarette addiction!
After smoking your last cigarette the night before your Quit Day, take a shower, wash your hair, and brush your teeth. Get rid of all the last traces of nicotine!
As your Quit Day approaches, we're going to share our "The Night Before Checklist" and "On Your Quit Day" series in this event. These are some final tips that we think are helpful :)
